Gimel.js API Reference¶

Main Methods¶

AddHTML¶

$g.addHTML(selector, html, [addmethod, numberselector]);()¶

Adds or sets the HTML content of an element.

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element you want to add HTML to. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • html (string) – The HTML you want to add.

  • addmethod (string) – How you want to add the HTML. If left out, it will over write any pre-existing HTML content. If set to add, it will add to pre-existing HTML content if any. Example-1.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector. This method supports the all property. Here-1 is an example of AddHTML using the all property.

Example¶

$g.addHTML("#demo", "<p>simply add any HTML <ins>anywhere</ins> in the page.</p>");

try-in-editor-1

AddCSS¶

$g.addCSS(selector, css, [addmethod, numberselector]);()¶

Adds or sets the inline CSS of an element.

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element you want to add CSS to. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • css (string) – The CSS you want to add.

  • addmethod (string) – How you want to add the CSS. If left out, it will over write any pre-existing inline CSS styles. If set to keep, it will add to pre-existing CSS styles if any. Example.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector. This method supports the all property. Here is an example of AddCSS using the all property.

Note

AddCSS will take first priority* over all other CSS styles; unless used with keep then it will take second priority and inline CSS first priority.

* By priority we mean how CSS styles will overwrite each other.

Example¶

$g.addCSS("#demo", "\
background-color: red;\
border: 2px solid #555;\
height: 6rem;\
width: 6rem;\
");

OR¶

$g.addCSS("#demo", "background-color: red; border: 2px solid #555;");

try-in-editor-2

AddClass¶

$g.addClass(selector, class, [numberselector]);()¶

Adds one or more CSS class to an HTML element.

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element you want to add the (CSS) class(es) to. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • class (string) – The CSS class(es) you want to add.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector.

Example¶

$g.addClass("#demo", "new");

try-in-editor-3

SetCSS¶

$g.setCSS(selector, property, value, [numberselector]);()¶

Sets or changes a single CSS style property of a element.

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element whos style you want to change. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • property (string) – The name of the property you want to change (only the name e.g. for color:red; place only color here: see example below).

  • value (string) – The value you want to set the CSS property to (e.g. for color:red; you would place red here: see example below).

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector. This method supports the all property. Here-3 is an example of setCSS using the all property.

Example¶

$g.setCSS("#demo", "background-color", "green");

try-in-editor-4

RemoveElement¶

$g.RemoveElement(selector, [numberselector]);()¶

Removes one or more HTML elements.

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element you want to remove/delete. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector. This method supports the all property. Here-4 is an example of removeElement using the all property.

Example¶

$g.removeElement(".demo", 0);

try-in-editor-5

SetProperty¶

$g.setProperty(selector, property, value, [numberselector]);()¶

Sets or changes a single property of an element (e.g. for an a tag, a property you might set/change could be href).

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element who’s property you want to change. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • property (string) – The name of the property you want to change (only the name e.g. for href="somewhere.html"; place only href here: see-example).

  • value (string) – The value you want to set the property to (e.g. for href="somewhere.html"; you would place somewhere.html here: see-example below).

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector.

Note

SetProperty method is not suggested for setting style or class properties. For this use AddCSS (or SetCSS) and AddClass.

Example¶

$g.setProperty("#demo", "type", "range");

try-in-editor-12

AddElement¶

$g.addElement(element, selector, Id, [numberselector]);()¶

Creates and appends an HTML element into your HTML document.

Arguments

  • element (string) – The element you want to create.

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element you want to append the created element to. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • Id (string) – The Id of the created element.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector.

Example¶

$g.addElement("input", ".demo", "new");

try-in-editor-14

Hide¶

$g.hide(selector, [numberselector]);()¶

Hides an HTML element.

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element you want to hide. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector.

Example¶

$g.hide("#demo");

try-in-editor-16

Show¶

$g.show(selector, [numberselector]);()¶

Shows an HTML element that has been hidden with the hide method.

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element you want to show. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector.

Example¶

$g.show("#demo");

try-in-editor-17

Event Methods¶

When¶

$g.when(selector, event, code, [numberselector]);()¶

Runs/executes your code “when” an event (e.g. an element is clicked) is triggered.

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element which will trigger the event. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • event (string) – The event that will trigger your code. You can use any single JavaScript event here. This is a list of accepted JavaScript Events. | Here-is-a-example of the some of the most used events.

  • code (string) – The JavaScript code (gimel.js or other) you wish to run when triggered.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector.

syntax¶

$g.when("_Selector_", "_Event_", function(){
// Code to run when triggered
});

Example¶

$g.when("button", "click", function(){
$g.addHTML("button", "<h3>See how it works!</h3>");
});

try-in-editor-8

WhenScrollTo¶

$g.whenScrollTo(selector, code, [numberselector]);()¶

Runs/executes your code “when” the HTML page is scrolled to the selected element.

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element which will, on reaching trigger your code. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • code (string) – The JavaScript code (gimel.js or other) you wish to run when triggered.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector.

syntax¶

$g.whenScrollTo("_Selector_", function(){
// Code to run when page is scrolled to selected element
});

Example¶

$g.whenScrollTo("#demo", function(){
$g.changeCSS("#demo" , "background-color" , "red");
});

try-in-editor-9

Note

This method (whenScrollTo) may not preform as expected on all devices. We are working to fix this.

WhenTimeUp¶

$g.whenTimeUp(time, code, [numberselector]);()¶

Runs/executes your code “when” time is up.

Arguments

  • time (integer) – The amount of time before the code is to be executed (time is in milliseconds: one second is equally to one hundred milliseconds). This-example of the whenTimeUp method shows the the use of timing.

  • code (string) – The JavaScript code (gimel.js or other) you wish to run when time is up.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector.

syntax¶

$g.whenTimeUp( time, function(){
// Code to run when time is up
});

Example¶

$g.whenTimeUp( 3000, function(){
$g.changeCSS("p", "font-size", "24px", 1);
});

try-in-editor-10

WhenToggle¶

$g.whenToggle(selector, first-code, second-code, [numberselector]);()¶

Runs/executes your code “when” the selected element is toggled.

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element which will toggle between the to sets of code. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • first-code (string) – The JavaScript code (gimel.js or other) you wish to run when first toggled.

  • second-code (string) – The JavaScript code (gimel.js or other) you wish to run when toggled for the second time.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector.

syntax¶

$g.whenToggle( "_Selector_", function(){
// Code to run when first triggered
},
function(){
// Code to run when triggered a second time
// Then it starts over
});

Example¶

$g.whenToggle( "#demo", function(){
$g.changeCSS(" #demo", "color", "red");
},
function(){
$g.changeCSS(" #demo", "color", "green");
});

try-in-editor-11

Note

The element being toggled dose not have to be the element on which the code applies. An-Example

Effect Methods¶

TypingEffect¶

$g.typingEffect(selector, html, time, [numberselector]);()¶

Sets a typing effect to the text of an element.

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element you want to add the typing effect to. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • html (string) – The text you want to type.

  • time (string) – How fast you want the text to be type. Here-is-an-example-showing-this.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector.

Example¶

// Time in milliseconds
$g.typingEffect("#demo", "Simple, Easy, Neat and most importantly FUN!", 170);

try-in-editor-13

Note

Do not use HTML as typing content, it will not render; as seen in this-example. You can still style text, just style the element you are typing the text in; like-this.

FadeIn¶

$g.fadeIn(selector, effect-name, effect-value, [clarity, numberselector]);()¶

Fades in a HTML element using a CSS transform effect.

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element you want to fade in. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • effect-name (string) – The name (only the name) of the CSS transform effect you want to use for your fade in. Here is a list of the CSS transform.

  • effect-value (string) – The value of the CSS transform effect (e.g. if you wanted translate(60px, 0px) as your fade in, the effect value would be (60px, 0px) ). Here is a list of the CSS transform.

  • clarity (string) – Whether you want your fade in to literally fade in (like-this-clear), or whether you want a solid face in (like-this-solid). The solid face in is for things like off canvas drawers. Clear is the default if left out; for the solid effect set to off as seen in the solid example.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector.

Important

The fadeIn method must.
1. Be called outside one of any Event Methods.
2. Must be used with the FadeInStart method.
You can think of the fadeIn method as setting up the fade in and the fadeInStart method as calling the fadeIn to begin. It is for this reason that the fadeIn method is always at the top in our examples.

Example¶

$g.fadeIn("#divOne", "translate3d", "(1rem, -4rem, 3rem)");

try-in-editor-6

FadeInStart¶

$g.fadeInStart(selector, effect-name, length, [numberselector]);()¶

Calls the fadeIn method to begin the fade in. This method (fadeInStart) is always placed inside an event method (See Event Methods and example below).

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element you want to fade in. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • effect-name (string) – The name (only the name) of the CSS transform effect you used in the fadeIn method for the selected element.

  • length (string) – The length of time (in seconds) that you want the fade in to last.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector.

Important

The fadeInStart method must.
1. Be called inside one of the Event Methods.
2. Must be used with the FadeIn method.
You can think of the fadeIn method as setting up the fade in and the fadeInStart method as calling the fadeIn to begin. It is for this reason that the fadeIn method is always at the top in our examples.

Example¶

$g.fadeInStart("#divOne", "translate", 2);

try-in-editor-7

fadeOutStart¶

$g.fadeOutStart(selector, effect-name, effect-value, length, [numberselector]);()¶

Fades out an HTML element using a CSS transform effect.

Arguments

  • selector (string) – CSS selector to select the element you want to fade out. Must be either an id, class name or tag name.

  • effect-name (string) – The name (only the name) of the CSS transform effect you used in the fadeOutStart method for the selected element.

  • effect-value (string) – The value of the CSS transform effect (e.g. if you wanted translate(60px, 0px) as your fade out, the effect value would be (60px, 0px) ). Here is a list of the CSS transform.

  • length (string) – The length of time (in seconds) that you want the fade out to last.

  • numberselector (integer) – See Number Selector.

Important

The fadeOutStart method must be called inside one of the Event Methods.
Unlike fadeIn and fadeInStart, fadeOutStart dose not need to be setup only called.

Example¶

$g.fadeOutStart("#divOne", "translate", "(0px, 50px)", 2);

try-in-editor-15
